posts.cooked: Which is better this year? This probably pertains most to the APIs, but other considerations are valid as well. One thing to note is that we will likely need 2 cameras. The only other piece of relevant information I can add is that we have the option of running Photonvision on a RPi4 which should be more powerful than the CM3 in our LL2.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
The annoying truth: Depends on what you define as “best”

I think a good, and very common definition of best is “scores most points”

Since we’re this far into build season, the best answer for scoring points is to just use whatever you know the best. Ramp-up time is going to be the limiting factor, not the software itself.

gerthworm:

Ramp-up time is going to be the limiting factor

Are you talking about coprocessor boot times or shooter spin-up?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.cooked: Neither, learning curve. Use the software you have the most experience with unless you are very confident you can learn the new software fast. if you have experience with neither I heavily encourage photon vision
I am going with photon vision for now (more of a hardware and wiring thing than anything else) do you think an OPi 5 is significant enough of an upgrade over an RPi 4 + Coral to be worthwhile?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Max
posts.cooked: I’ve done some testing with Photon Vision using an Orange Pi 5 and a global shutter arducam, and the only things that we struggle to get up to 60 FPS (we stick to 60, but we can get up to 100) are the colored shapes, which are replaceable by the retro-reflective pipeline type, and the ML model, but it gets to 31 FPS, and thats to be expected. All in all, if you struggle to get 60 FPS at a good latency, or have the money to spare, I would recommend getting one.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: I recommend running it at 100fps capture so that you can get a more reliable 60fps. I see the framerste drop a hair sometimes, which means it might miss a camera frame/robot loop. This is more unlikely to happen if you match to 50fps (though still possible for other reasons).

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Hello

I am a bit late to the party, but I feel that the release of the Limelight 3G Introducing Limelight 3G - FIRST / General Forum - Chief Delphi is ground for reactivating this sleepy thread.

Team 2495 has extensively relied on Limelight 2 back when retroreflective tape was the cool stuff, as well as the excellent FRCVision/WPILibPi wpilibsuite/WPILibPi: WPILib Raspberry Pi images designed for FRC (formerly FRCVision) (github.com) for pure camera streaming.

We were planning to try LL2 + Google Coral for object detection but never found the time to try it off-season. We understood that the fact that the LL2 used a rolling shutter camera for AprilTag processing was nonoptimal.

So, this season, after we heard good things about the Orange Pi and Photonvision combo from our mother team, we gave it a try. One fairly reasonably priced piece of hardware that can do AprilTag processing, object detection and basic video streaming is very appealing.

And I think that we did properly leverage the combo, earning an Innovation In Control award yesterday.

But getting there has been more painful than I expected. We had to give up connecting two Lifecams to the same Orange Pi as it didn’t seem to work. We slapped back our trusted old Raspberry Pi running  FRCVision/WPILibPi to handle vision.

Then while AprilTag processing works perfectly, we do observe a lot of bugs on the object detection side, as described in a couple of posts under the PhotonVision OjectDetection camera sometimes missing on boot - Technical / PhotonVision - Chief Delphi thread.

We had to play pretty much all our matches on Sunday without object detection, and that definitively slowed us in the Finals.

So, while anxiously waiting for a bugfix for a bug that has somehow been closed as duplicate PhotonVision OjectDetection camera sometimes missing on boot · Issue #1273 · PhotonVision/photonvision (github.com) , I am wondering if we shouldn’t have tried LL2 + Google Coral for object detection instead.

And now that LL3G is out, I’m thinking that a combination of LL2 + Google Coral for object detection and LL3G for AprilTag processing, while expensive, might be a wiser choice for teams that can afford it.

Of course, the grass is always greener on the other side. I’m looking forward to hearing feedback on the LL2 + Google Coral as well as the LL3G.
